Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will create a Bachelor of Science in electrical engineering program for military veterans supported by the Post 9/11 GI Bill. To address veterans' needs the project will create a start-to-finish, high quality 36-month accelerated course of study. Key elements of the proposed program are focused recruiting strategies with broad accessibility of program information, considering veterans' life experience, and creation of an intensive math bridge program with an on-line tutoring component to help retain students in the program.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to address a specific, targeted group of veterans, and get them quickly into the engineering workforce. The lessons learned from this program will inform the education community's knowledge-base on effective methods to structure programs so that veteran students have a high chance to succeed in engineering degree programs. The project specifically addresses skills in mathematics, which often present obstacles to degree completion.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Abstract at Time of Award Eastern Washington University (EWU), a comprehensive university that serves the vast rural region of Eastern Washington, proposes to offer a Bachelor of Science in electrical engineering program specifically designed for military veterans supported by the Post 9/11 GI Bill. The core of VeteransÃ† Electrical Engineering Program is a start to finish high quality 36-month course of study. It includes targeted recruitment of veterans with the potential for college, a cohort model that serves 15-18 new students each year; the opportunity for students to receive credit for prior learning; a veteransÃ† only bridge program focused on math skills development; customized support including intensive mentoring and advising; and internships and other applied experiences with industry and potential employers. This project is a capacity building grant. EWU intends to begin the project with grant funding and institutionalize the program as it becomes established. This process includes immediate use of university resources to supplement the current project as well as a commitment to continue funding in support of a special faculty member who will teach, advise, and mentor veteran students served by the program. Outcomes Report The nation has a severe need for a more technically proficient workforce, more specifically in electrical engineering, where retiring baby boomers are leaving hard-to-fill vacancies in the workforce. At the same time, we have a largely untapped resource of highly trained veterans returning home. In an effort to repay the services of veterans and to fill our need for more engineers, EWU created a special program for student veterans to finish their coursework in electrical engineering in 36 months, i.e. the allotted support time provided by the Post 9/11 GI Bill. The program includes a bridge class focused on developing math skills, which was utilized by veterans that have been away from the classroom for some time and need to fine tune their skills in preparation for the intense engineering curriculum. As of this writing all students remaining in the program are expected to graduate within the planned timeline. These students are maintaining a GPA of 3.0 or above in departmental and science classes. Our Advisory Board has expressed a keen interest in the program and many industrial partners have stated that they will consider interviewing student veterans for future openings. A VeteranÃ†s Resource Center (VRC) was created that helps students navigate through the academic environment and serves as a meeting place for all student veterans. All veteran recruiting has been The VRC has intensified targeted recruitment and it is expected that in two years we will grow at the number stated in the objective (or more). Note that all recruitment and mentoring costs have already been absorbed by Eastern Washington University.
